thread.title: Harris County offers first free spay and neuter event
thread.title_full: Harris County offers first free spay and neuter event

author: Katherine Blunt
title: Harris County offers first free spay and neuter event
text:
Close Image 1 of 3 Ashley McCown volunteers Saturday at the Harris County Animal Shelter's "Fix It" spay and neuter event, which was the largest Harris County has organized to raise awareness about an ongoing overpopulation of homeless animals. The shelter spayed about 200 pets. less Ashley McCown volunteers Saturday at the Harris County Animal Shelter's "Fix It" spay and neuter event, which was the largest Harris County has organized to raise awareness about an ongoing overpopulation of ... more Photo: Tim Warner, Freelance Image 2 of 3 Kamilla Ventura shares custody of her cat, Cirila, with her mother during the "Fix It" spay and neuter event at the Harris County Animal Shelter in Houston on Saturday. Kamilla Ventura shares custody of her cat, Cirila, with her mother during the "Fix It" spay and neuter event at the Harris County Animal Shelter in Houston on Saturday. Photo: Tim Warner, Freelance The Harris County Animal shelter houses roughly 270 stray animals on any given day. The Harris County Animal shelter houses roughly 270 stray animals on any given day. Photo: Tim Warner, Freelance Harris County offers first free spay and neuter event 1 / 3 Back to Gallery 
The black-and-white Chihuahua mix quivered at his owner's feet, frozen with fear. Little did he know he would be emerging from the clinic just a little bit less male. 
Other less-suspecting dogs scampered as far as their leashes would allow, sniffing and jumping in blissful ignorance. And the felines, always enigmatic, quietly judged the situation from within their mesh carriers. 
All 200 animals arrived at the Harris County Animal Shelter to get fixed for free Saturday. It was the first time the county had organized such a large event, meant to encourage residents in unincorporated areas to spay and neuter their pets and raise awareness about an ongoing overpopulation problem. 
The shelter, already overflowing, receives 60 to 80 unwanted dogs and cats each day. Some are fostered or adopted, but not all. 
"We've got to stop this influx of unwanted animals," said Michael White , director of the county's Veterinary Public Health division . 
The shelter's adoption rate has gone up since White assumed his position about three and a half years ago, and its euthanasia rate has gone down. But its adoption rate for dogs still hovers near 75 percent, and for cats, it's much lower, he said. 
Pet owners began lining up hours before the start of the "Fix It" event, carried out mostly by volunteers in the early hours of the day. The 200 slots filled up far quicker than expected, organizers said, and some people showed up without appointments hoping their animals could join the lineup. 
Luz Vasquez strolled through the parking lot with a manic Yorkie at the end of a leash and a quiet one in a leopard print carrier that could pass as a purse at first glance. She immediately signed both up for appointments when she heard the service would be free. 
"It's expensive at the vet," she said. 
Megan Cantu 's Pomeranian mix clung to her shoulder, peeking warily from beneath long blonde eyebrows. The dog had puppies once before, challenging her owners to give them all away. 
"It's just hard to find homes for all of them," Cantu said. 
Nearby, a pureblood German Shepherd named Gracie basked in attention, licking anyone who ventured close enough. It wasn't always that way - she had been abandoned on Houston's north side before her new owner, Shawn Walton , took her in to join the other fosters he and his wife care for in Baytown. 
They now have about 10 dogs, but the number changes as the animals come and go. Gracie, however, is there to stay, Walton said. 
"She came in and was so happy to have a home," he said. "She sleeps across the tops of our heads at night." 
Inside the shelter, volunteers readied the animals for anesthesia. It's a quick procedure - 15 minutes in the hands of a skillful vet. 
In the adjoining rooms, dogs in kennels clamored for attention from anyone who walked by. White, who fosters as many as 12 dogs at a time, put two small puppies up for adoption Saturday, adding to the roughly 270 animals that the shelter typically houses. 
"It's important for us to find forever homes for them," he said. Latest from the Chron.com Homepage Click below for the top news from around the Houston area and beyond.
